sn24.2:1.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.2:1.3: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn24.2:1.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn24.2:1.5: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.2:1.6: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn24.2:1.10: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn24.2:1.11: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn24.2:2.12: “That which is seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.2:2.14: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.2:2.16: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.2:2.17: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn24.2:3.1: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt in these six cases, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
sn24.2:3.2: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
